knowledge.summary: A Linked List is a linear data structure consisting of a sequence of nodes connected via links (pointers). Each node contains a data part and a reference to the next node, forming a chain.
key_points: Nodes in a linked list are not stored contiguously, unlike arrays or other types of linear data structures.
Each node in a linked list has a link (pointer) that points to the next node, creating a sequence of nodes.
Linked lists can dynamically grow and shrink during runtime.
knowledge.common_confusion: A common mistake for beginners is forgetting to initialize the head pointer or linking the last node to NULL in a singly linked list.

knowledge.summary: A Node is a data structure that stores both data and a reference to another node, creating a sequence in memory known as a linked list.
key_points: Each node contains a piece of data (usually an integer or object) and a pointer to the next node in the sequence.
The last node in a linked list has a null or empty pointer, indicating the end of the list.
Linked lists allow dynamic resizing as new nodes can be added or removed without rearranging the existing data.
knowledge.common_confusion: Beginners often forget to set the next pointer of the last node correctly, leading to an incorrect linked list structure.

knowledge.summary: A next pointer is a reference variable in a linked list that stores the memory address of the subsequent node. It allows traversal through the nodes sequentially.
key_points: Each node in a linked list contains a data part and a link (next) to the next node
The next pointer of the last node usually points to NULL
Traversing a linked list means following the next pointers from one node to another
knowledge.common_confusion: Beginners may sometimes forget to initialize the next pointer when creating new nodes.

knowledge.summary: The head of a linked list is the first node in the list. It contains the data and a reference to the next node in the sequence.
key_points: The head node is crucial as it defines where the list starts.
It stores both the data and the link to the following node.
In most cases, accessing or manipulating the linked list operations start with the head.
knowledge.common_confusion: A common mistake for beginners is to forget that the head is a regular node in the linked list.

knowledge.summary: The tail of a linked list is the last node in the list.
key_points: It does not contain any next pointers, as it is the end of the chain.
Finding the tail is useful for operations such as appending new nodes.
In many implementations, accessing the tail requires traversing the entire list.
knowledge.common_confusion: A common mistake is to think that the last node has a next pointer pointing to null. However, in practice, it's more common for the last node to have no next pointer at all.

knowledge.summary: Adding a new node to an existing linked list at a specific position.
key_points: Inserts a new node, containing data and a link to the next node (if any).
Requires knowledge of the position where the insertion should occur.
Inserting at the beginning of the list involves updating the first node's previous link.
knowledge.common_confusion: Forgetting to update the links of the existing nodes can lead to an incorrect linked list structure.

knowledge.summary: Removing a node from a linked list.
key_points: Locate the node to be deleted (usually by traversing through the list).
Store the value of the node you want to remove in a temporary variable.
Update the pointer of the previous node pointing to the next node of the node to be removed.
knowledge.common_confusion: Forgetting to handle the case when the node to be deleted is the head (first) node of the list.

knowledge.summary: A Singly Linked List is a linear data structure where each element, called a node, consists of data and a reference (pointer) to the next node in the sequence.
key_points: Each node has only one next pointer
The last node has a NULL or NEXT as its next pointer
Efficient for insertion and deletion at any position
knowledge.common_confusion: A common mistake is forgetting to set the next pointer of the new node when adding a node to the end of the list.

knowledge.summary: A doubly linked list is a data structure that allows traversal in both directions (forward and backward) from each node.
key_points: Each node contains a data part, a reference to the next node, and a reference to the previous node.
Offers fast insertion and deletion operations at any position.
Can be implemented using arrays or linked lists for memory management.
knowledge.common_confusion: One common beginner mistake is forgetting to update the previous pointer while adding a new node in the beginning of the list.

knowledge.summary: A linked list is a linear data structure where elements are connected through references, also known as pointers.
key_points: Each element of a linked list, called a node, contains a piece of data and a reference to the next node in the sequence.
The last node in a linked list has no successor (next node), and this is indicated by setting its pointer to NULL or NIL.
Linked lists are dynamic as they can grow and shrink during runtime, unlike arrays.
knowledge.common_confusion: A common mistake is forgetting that the last node in a linked list has no next node.

knowledge.summary: The actions performed on a Node in a Linked List
key_points: Accessing or modifying the data and/or next pointer of a Node
Insertion of a new Node before, after or at specific position
Deletion of an existing Node
knowledge.common_confusion: Beginners may confuse Linked Lists with Arrays. Remember, accessing a specific index in an Array is constant time O(1), while in Linked List it can be O(n) due to the need to traverse the list.

knowledge.summary: The head pointer in a linked list points to the first node of the list.
key_points: It is a variable that holds the address of the first node in the list.
When traversing the list, the head pointer keeps updating to point to the next node until it reaches the end.
In many programming languages like C and Java, the head pointer is often called 'head' or 'first'.
knowledge.common_confusion: Beginners might forget to initialize the head pointer before using it, causing null pointer errors.

knowledge.summary: The time complexity of operations in a linked list depends on the position of the node. Basic operations like insertion, deletion at the end have O(1) time complexity, but for accessing elements or finding the middle, it's O(n), where n is the number of nodes.
key_points: Insertion and deletion at the end are constant time operations
Accessing elements or finding the middle takes linear time
knowledge.common_confusion: It's a common mistake to assume that all linked list operations have the same O(1) complexity.
